results.title: The Jointed-legged animals: arthropods
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
This film shows the jointed-legged animals and the structural and functional characteristics of animals in the phylum arthropoda: examples from each of the five classes, and their evolutionary development. Metamorphosis and moulting processes are illustrated using photo-micrography and time-lapse photography. The economic importance to man is discussed. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Flatworms: platyhelminthes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
After brief views of land, fresh water, marine and parasitic flatworms, shows the important characteristics of the common planaria. These are the simplest animals with bilateral symmetry, a distinct head, a central nervous system and a substantially developed mesoderm layer. Their regenerative ability is demonstrated, showing polarity, the anterior-posterior gradient and cell dominance.

results.title: Fish embryo from fertilization to hatching
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Illustrates how fish eggs are fertilised in a stream, then traces the development of the zygote from the first cell cleavage to the formation of a young fish. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The First many-celled animals: sponges
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Demonstrates that the sponge represents one development of multicellularity in animals. Shows life processes and the adaptation of sponges to their environment. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Echinoderms: sea stars and their relatives
results.brief_description:
Episode of series “Biology program. Unit 3. Animal life”
Describes the characteristics of the echinoderm body plan and shows how it adapted for locomotion, respiration, digestion and reproduction. Includes examples of the five classes of echinodeerms.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

Episode of series “Biology program. Unit 3. Animal life”

results.title: Army ants: a study in social behaviour
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
This film depicts two species of army ants in the Panama Canal zone. It presents the basic structure of an ant colony and the behaviour of the ants and shows evidence of stimuli which influence their behaviour. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: What is ecology?
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Introduces the study of ecology by illustrating the wide variety of interrelationships between plants, animals and their environment. Introduces the major biomes of the world.

results.title: The Temperate deciduous forest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 1. Ecology”
Illustrates the complex network of plant and animal relationships that make up the temperate deciduous forest community. Shows the adaptations of animals and deciduous plants to seasonal changes.

results.title: Succession on lava
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”
Illustrates the destruction caused by a volcanic eruption in Hawaii, and examines the difficulties encountered by the first forms of life that re-appear. Traces the stages of ecological succession, from the blue-green algae to the re-establishment of a mature biotic community.
